comment_text.mn75:1.1: The wanderer Māgaṇḍiya appears outraged at the presence of the Buddha, who he thinks stands in opposition to life itself since he opposes sensual enjoyment. It soon turns out that he misunderstands the Buddha’s teachings on sensuality, as the Buddha’s aim is not to prevent people from experiencing pleasure but to elevate them so they can enjoy a higher form of pleasure.
comment_text.mn75:3.1: A Māgaṇḍiya appears here and in Snp 4.9, where he uses his beautiful daughter to tempt the Buddha (cited and discussed at SN 22.3). As to the protagonist of Snp 4.9, the Pali commentary, Divyāvadāna 36—which calls him Mākandika—and the Chinese parallel in the Arthapada (T iv 180) say he too was from the Kuru country. Now, the Mahābhārata and other Sanskrit sources name Mākandī as a city or province on the banks of the Ganges, in the Pañcāla kingdom south of Hastināpura. This more-or-less agrees with Māgaṇḍiya’s home in the Kuru country, and suggests his name means “the man from Mākandī”. Divyāvadāna 36 and Sanskrit fragment say the Mākandika of Snp 4.9 was also a wanderer, which does not contradict the position of the Pali commentaries and the Arthapada that he was a brahmin. At AN 5.294–302:1.1, māgaṇḍika is listed as a type of ascetic; these could well be students of Māgaṇḍiya. Kathāsaritsāgara 15 tells the comic farce of an ascetic from Mākandikā on the banks of the Ganges, who fell in love with the daughter of a merchant and went to ridiculous lengths to obtain her, only to end up a laughing-stock. This story could well have begun life as a comic inversion of Snp 4.9. Reading all these sources together, we can posit that there was a brahmin wanderer from Mākandī on the Ganges in Kuru-Pañcāla, who gained a certain fame and following as a teacher, but whose hedonism was his downfall. The Pali commentaries further specify that the Māgaṇḍiya of the current sutta is the nephew of the one at Snp 4.9.
comment_text.mn75:5.3: Bhūnahan is Sanskrit bhrūṇahan. The earliest sense is “fetus-killer”, found in Rig Veda 10.155.2a where a grotesque demoness is cursed as one who “slays all fetuses” (sarvā bhrūṇāny āruṣī), and also at Atharvaveda 6.1112.3c (bhrūṇaghni). They are listed among heinous folk at Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.22 (Olivelle: “abortionist”). Later it took on the sense “murderer of a brahmin”. It is used in Pali for a depraved person, especially one who destroys the life of a developed fetus or child (see AN 7.64:22.1, Ja 358:1.1, Ja 544:105.2). | The brahmin of Verañja calls the Buddha a variety of names at AN 8.11.
comment_text.mn75:5.10: Sutta can mean “discourse” or “sleeping”. I do not know anywhere else in the Pali where non-Buddhist texts are referred to as sutta. Further, it would seem unlikely that they had such a prophecy of the Buddha, and no early Brahmanical texts have anything like this. On the other hand, the Upaniṣads feature many passages on sleep and dream, and the importance of the visions therein (eg. Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.1.18). Also, avacarati is not, so far as I know, used for the “transmission” of scripture, but it is used for the “descent” from heaven (Rig Veda 10.59.9a), a usage fitting well the appearance of a vision in a dream. | The plural no (“our”) here is not significant, as Māgaṇḍiya refers to himself with the royal “we”.
comment_text.mn75:10.13: Samadhigayha tiṭṭhati means “stands at the same level”, “equals” not “surpasses” (Iti 23:2.1, MN 78:8.8).

root_text.mn75:17.3: evameva kho, māgaṇḍiya, sattā kāmesu avītarāgā kāmataṇhāhi khajjamānā kāmapariḷāhena ca pariḍayhamānā kāme paṭisevanti.
root_text.mn75:17.4: Yathā yathā kho, māgaṇḍiya, sattā kāmesu avītarāgā kāmataṇhāhi khajjamānā kāmapariḷāhena ca pariḍayhamānā kāme paṭisevanti tathā tathā tesaṁ tesaṁ sattānaṁ kāmataṇhā ceva pavaḍḍhati, kāmapariḷāhena ca pariḍayhanti, hoti ceva sātamattā assādamattā—yadidaṁ pañcakāmaguṇe paṭicca.
root_text.mn75:18.2: api nu te diṭṭho vā suto vā rājā vā rājamahāmatto vā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricārayamāno kāmataṇhaṁ appahāya kāmapariḷāhaṁ appaṭivinodetvā vigatapipāso ajjhattaṁ vūpasantacitto vihāsi vā viharati vā viharissati vā”ti?
root_text.mn75:18.5: Mayāpi kho etaṁ, māgaṇḍiya, neva diṭṭhaṁ na sutaṁ rājā vā rājamahāmatto vā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricārayamāno kāmataṇhaṁ appahāya kāmapariḷāhaṁ appaṭivinodetvā vigatapipāso ajjhattaṁ vūpasantacitto vihāsi vā viharati vā viharissati vā.
root_text.mn75:18.6: Atha kho, māgaṇḍiya, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā vigatapipāsā ajjhattaṁ vūpasantacittā vihāsuṁ vā viharanti vā viharissanti vā sabbe te kāmānaṁyeva samudayañca atthaṅgamañca assādañca ādīnavañca nissaraṇañca yathābhūtaṁ viditvā kāmataṇhaṁ pahāya kāmapariḷāhaṁ paṭivinodetvā vigatapipāsā ajjhattaṁ vūpasantacittā vihāsuṁ vā viharanti vā viharissanti vā”ti.
root_text.mn75:19.1: Atha kho bhagavā tāyaṁ velāyaṁ imaṁ udānaṁ udānesi:
root_text.mn75:19.6: Evaṁ vutte, māgaṇḍiyo paribbājako bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn75:19.10: Mayāpi kho etaṁ, bho gotama, sutaṁ pubbakānaṁ paribbājakānaṁ ācariyapācariyānaṁ bhāsamānānaṁ:
root_text.mn75:19.13: “Yaṁ pana te etaṁ, māgaṇḍiya, sutaṁ pubbakānaṁ paribbājakānaṁ ācariyapācariyānaṁ bhāsamānānaṁ:
root_text.mn75:19.14: ‘ārogyaparamā lābhā, nibbānaṁ paramaṁ sukhan’ti, katamaṁ taṁ ārogyaṁ, katamaṁ taṁ nibbānan”ti?
root_text.mn75:19.15: Evaṁ vutte, māgaṇḍiyo paribbājako sakāneva sudaṁ gattāni pāṇinā anomajjati:
root_text.mn75:19.17: Ahañhi, bho gotama, etarahi arogo sukhī, na maṁ kiñci ābādhatī”ti.

root_text.mn75:21.1: “Evameva kho, māgaṇḍiya, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā andhā acakkhukā ajānantā ārogyaṁ, apassantā nibbānaṁ, atha ca panimaṁ gāthaṁ bhāsanti:
root_text.mn75:21.3: Pubbakehesā, māgaṇḍiya, arahantehi sammāsambuddhehi gāthā bhāsitā:
root_text.mn75:21.9: Ayaṁ kho pana, māgaṇḍiya, kāyo rogabhūto gaṇḍabhūto sallabhūto aghabhūto ābādhabhūto, so tvaṁ imaṁ kāyaṁ rogabhūtaṁ gaṇḍabhūtaṁ sallabhūtaṁ aghabhūtaṁ ābādhabhūtaṁ:
root_text.mn75:21.10: ‘idantaṁ, bho gotama, ārogyaṁ, idantaṁ nibbānan’ti vadesi.
root_text.mn75:21.11: Tañhi te, māgaṇḍiya, ariyaṁ cakkhuṁ natthi yena tvaṁ ariyena cakkhunā ārogyaṁ jāneyyāsi, nibbānaṁ passeyyāsī”ti.
root_text.mn75:22.2: Pahoti me bhavaṁ gotamo tathā dhammaṁ desetuṁ yathāhaṁ ārogyaṁ jāneyyaṁ, nibbānaṁ passeyyan”ti.
root_text.mn75:22.4: so na passeyya kaṇhasukkāni rūpāni, na passeyya nīlakāni rūpāni, na passeyya pītakāni rūpāni, na passeyya lohitakāni rūpāni, na passeyya mañjiṭṭhakāni rūpāni, na passeyya samavisamaṁ, na passeyya tārakarūpāni, na passeyya candimasūriye.

root_text.mn75:22.7: So taṁ bhesajjaṁ āgamma na cakkhūni uppādeyya, na cakkhūni visodheyya.
root_text.mn75:22.9: nanu so vejjo yāvadeva kilamathassa vighātassa bhāgī assā”ti?

root_text.mn75:22.13: So mamassa kilamatho, sā mamassa vihesā”ti.

root_text.mn75:24.3: So tvaṁ ārogyaṁ jāneyyāsi, nibbānaṁ passeyyāsi.
root_text.mn75:24.4: Tassa te saha cakkhuppādā yo pañcasupādānakkhandhesu chandarāgo so pahīyetha;
root_text.mn75:24.6: ‘dīgharattaṁ vata bho ahaṁ iminā cittena nikato vañcito paluddho.
root_text.mn75:24.7: Ahañhi rūpaṁyeva upādiyamāno upādiyiṁ, vedanaṁyeva upādiyamāno upādiyiṁ, saññaṁyeva upādiyamāno upādiyiṁ, saṅkhāreyeva upādiyamāno upādiyiṁ, viññāṇaṁyeva upādiyamāno upādiyiṁ.
root_text.mn75:24.8: Tassa me upādānapaccayā bhavo, bhavapaccayā jāti, jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā sambhavanti;
root_text.mn75:25.2: Pahoti me bhavaṁ gotamo tathā dhammaṁ desetuṁ yathāhaṁ imamhā āsanā anandho vuṭṭhaheyyan”ti.
root_text.mn75:25.4: Yato kho tvaṁ, māgaṇḍiya, sappurise bhajissasi tato tvaṁ, māgaṇḍiya, saddhammaṁ sossasi;
root_text.mn75:25.5: yato kho tvaṁ, māgaṇḍiya, saddhammaṁ sossasi tato tvaṁ, māgaṇḍiya, dhammānudhammaṁ paṭipajjissasi;
root_text.mn75:25.6: yato kho tvaṁ, māgaṇḍiya, dhammānudhammaṁ paṭipajjissasi tato tvaṁ, māgaṇḍiya, sāmaṁyeva ñassasi, sāmaṁ dakkhissasi—
root_text.mn75:25.8: idha rogā gaṇḍā sallā aparisesā nirujjhanti.
root_text.mn75:25.9: Tassa me upādānanirodhā bhavanirodho, bhavanirodhā jātinirodho, jātinirodhā jarāmaraṇaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā nirujjhanti;
root_text.mn75:26.1: Evaṁ vutte, māgaṇḍiyo paribbājako bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn75:26.3: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṁ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṁ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṁ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṁ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
root_text.mn75:26.4: Esāhaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
root_text.mn75:26.5: Labheyyāhaṁ bhoto gotamassa santike pabbajjaṁ, labheyyaṁ upasampadan”ti.
root_text.mn75:27.1: “Yo kho, māgaṇḍiya, aññatitthiyapubbo imasmiṁ dhammavinaye ākaṅkhati pabbajjaṁ, ākaṅkhati upasampadaṁ, so cattāro māse parivasati; catunnaṁ māsānaṁ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājenti, upasampādenti bhikkhubhāvāya.
root_text.mn75:27.3: “Sace, bhante, aññatitthiyapubbā imasmiṁ dhammavinaye ākaṅkhantā pabbajjaṁ, ākaṅkhantā upasampadaṁ cattāro māse parivasanti, catunnaṁ māsānaṁ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājenti upasampādenti bhikkhubhāvāya; ahaṁ cattāri vassāni parivasissāmi, catunnaṁ vassānaṁ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājentu, upasampādentu bhikkhubhāvāyā”ti.
root_text.mn75:28.1: Alattha kho māgaṇḍiyo paribbājako bhagavato santike pabbajjaṁ, alattha upasampadaṁ.
root_text.mn75:28.2: Acirūpasampanno kho panāyasmā māgaṇḍiyo eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṁ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
root_text.mn75:28.3: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
root_text.mn75:28.4: Aññataro kho panāyasmā māgaṇḍiyo arahataṁ ahosīti.

translation_text.mn75:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kurus, near the Kuru town named Kammāsadamma, on a grass mat in the fire chamber of a brahmin of the Bhāradvāja clan.
translation_text.mn75:2.1: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Kammāsadamma for alms.
translation_text.mn75:2.2: He wandered for alms in Kammāsadamma. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to a certain forest grove for the day’s meditation.
translation_text.mn75:2.3: Having plunged deep into it, he sat at the root of a certain tree to meditate.
translation_text.mn75:3.1: Then as the wanderer Māgaṇḍiya was going for a walk he approached that fire chamber.
translation_text.mn75:3.2: He saw the grass mat spread out there
translation_text.mn75:3.3: and asked the brahmin of the Bhāradvāja clan,
translation_text.mn75:3.4: “Worthy Bhāradvāja, who has this grass mat been spread out for? It looks like an ascetic’s bed.”
translation_text.mn75:4.1: “There is the ascetic Gotama, a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family.
translation_text.mn75:4.3: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
translation_text.mn75:4.4: This bed has been spread for that worthy Gotama.”
translation_text.mn75:5.1: “Well, it’s a sad sight, worthy Bhāradvāja,
translation_text.mn75:5.3: to see a bed for the worthy Gotama, that baby-killer!”
translation_text.mn75:5.6: Many astute aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and ascetics are devoted to the worthy Gotama. They’ve been guided by him in the noble system, the skillful teaching.”
translation_text.mn75:5.7: “Even if I was to see the worthy Gotama face to face, worthy Bhāradvāja, I would say to his face:
translation_text.mn75:5.10: For so it came to me while sleeping.”
translation_text.mn75:5.11: “If you don’t mind, I’ll tell the ascetic Gotama about this.”
translation_text.mn75:5.12: “Don’t worry, worthy Bhāradvāja. You may tell him exactly what I’ve said.”
translation_text.mn75:6.1: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, the Buddha heard this discussion between the brahmin of the Bhāradvāja clan and the wanderer Māgaṇḍiya.
translation_text.mn75:6.2: Coming out of retreat, he went to the brahmin’s fire chamber and sat on the grass mat.
translation_text.mn75:6.3: Then the brahmin of the Bhāradvāja clan went to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.mn75:6.4: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,
translation_text.mn75:6.5: “Bhāradvāja, did you have a discussion with the wanderer Māgaṇḍiya about this grass mat?”
translation_text.mn75:6.6: When he said this, the brahmin, shocked and awestruck, said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn75:6.7: “I wanted to mention this very thing to the worthy Gotama,
translation_text.mn75:6.8: but you brought it up before I had a chance.”
translation_text.mn75:7.1: But this conversation between the Buddha and the brahmin was left unfinished.
translation_text.mn75:7.2: Then as the wanderer Māgaṇḍiya was going for a walk he approached that fire chamber. He went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

translation_text.mn75:9.2: Take someone who used to amuse themselves with sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing. Some time later—having truly understood the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape of sights, and having given up craving and dispelled passion for sights—they would live rid of thirst, their mind peaceful inside.
translation_text.mn75:9.3: What would you have to say to them, Māgaṇḍiya?”
translation_text.mn75:9.6: Take someone who used to amuse themselves with sounds known by the ear …
translation_text.mn75:9.9: touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
translation_text.mn75:9.10: Some time later—having truly understood the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape of touches, and having given up craving and dispelled passion for touches—they would live rid of thirst, their mind peaceful inside.
translation_text.mn75:9.11: What would you have to say to them, Māgaṇḍiya?”
translation_text.mn75:10.1: “Well, when I was still a layperson I used to amuse myself, supplied and provided with sights known by the eye … sounds known by the ear …
translation_text.mn75:10.4: touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
translation_text.mn75:10.6: one for the rainy season, one for the winter, and one for the summer.
translation_text.mn75:10.7: I stayed in a stilt longhouse without coming downstairs for the four months of the rainy season, where I was entertained by musicians—none of them men.
translation_text.mn75:10.8: Some time later—having truly understood the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape of sensual pleasures, and having given up craving and dispelled passion for sensual pleasures—I live rid of thirst, my mind peaceful inside.
translation_text.mn75:10.9: I see other sentient beings who are not free from sensual pleasures being consumed by craving for sensual pleasures, burning with passion for sensual pleasures, indulging in sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn75:10.10: I don’t envy them, nor do I hope to enjoy that.
translation_text.mn75:10.12: Because there is a satisfaction that is apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities,
translation_text.mn75:10.14: Enjoying that satisfaction, I don’t envy what is inferior, nor do I hope to enjoy it.
translation_text.mn75:11.1: Suppose there was a householder or a householder’s child who was rich, affluent, and wealthy. And they would amuse themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation. That is, sights known by the eye …
translation_text.mn75:11.3: touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
translation_text.mn75:11.4: Having practiced good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, when their body breaks up, after death, they’d be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm, in the company of the gods of the thirty-three.
translation_text.mn75:11.5: There they’d amuse themselves in the Garden of Delight, escorted by a band of nymphs, supplied and provided with the five kinds of heavenly sensual stimulation.
translation_text.mn75:11.6: Then they’d see a householder or a householder’s child amusing themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
translation_text.mn75:11.7: What do you think, Māgaṇḍiya? Would that god—amusing themselves in the Garden of Delight, escorted by a band of nymphs, supplied and provided with the five kinds of heavenly sensual stimulation—envy that householder or householder’s child their five kinds of human sensual stimulation, or return to human sensual pleasures?”
translation_text.mn75:11.10: Because heavenly sensual pleasures are better than human sensual pleasures.”
translation_text.mn75:12.1: “In the same way, Māgaṇḍiya, when I was still a layperson I used to entertain myself with sights … sounds …
translation_text.mn75:12.4: touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
translation_text.mn75:12.5: Some time later—having truly understood the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape of sensual pleasures, and having given up craving and dispelled passion for sensual pleasures—I live rid of thirst, my mind peaceful inside.
translation_text.mn75:12.6: I see other sentient beings who are not free from sensual pleasures being consumed by craving for sensual pleasures, burning with passion for sensual pleasures, indulging in sensual pleasures. I don’t envy them, nor do I hope to enjoy that.
translation_text.mn75:12.8: Because there is a satisfaction that is apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities,
translation_text.mn75:12.10: Enjoying that satisfaction, I don’t envy what is inferior, nor do I hope to enjoy it.
translation_text.mn75:13.1: Suppose there was a person affected by leprosy, with sores and blisters on their limbs. Being devoured by worms, scratching with their nails at the opening of their wounds, they’d cauterize their body over a pit of glowing coals.
translation_text.mn75:13.2: Their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a surgeon to treat them.
translation_text.mn75:13.3: The surgeon would make medicine for them,
translation_text.mn75:13.4: and by using that they’d be cured of leprosy. They’d be healthy, happy, autonomous, master of themselves, able to go where they wanted.
translation_text.mn75:13.5: Then they’d see another person affected by leprosy, with sores and blisters on their limbs, being devoured by worms, scratching with their nails at the opening of their wounds, cauterizing their body over a pit of glowing coals.
translation_text.mn75:13.7: Would that person envy that other person affected by leprosy for their pit of glowing coals or for taking medicine?”
translation_text.mn75:13.10: Because you need to take medicine only when there’s a disease. When there’s no disease, there’s no need for medicine.”
translation_text.mn75:14.1: “In the same way, Māgaṇḍiya, when I was still a layperson I used to entertain myself with sights … sounds …
translation_text.mn75:14.4: touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
translation_text.mn75:14.5: Some time later—having truly understood the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape of sensual pleasures, and having given up craving and dispelled passion for sensual pleasures—I live rid of thirst, my mind peaceful inside.
translation_text.mn75:14.6: I see other sentient beings who are not free from sensual pleasures being consumed by craving for sensual pleasures, burning with passion for sensual pleasures, indulging in sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn75:14.7: I don’t envy them, nor do I hope to enjoy that.
translation_text.mn75:14.9: Because there is a satisfaction that is apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities,
translation_text.mn75:14.11: Enjoying that satisfaction, I don’t envy what is inferior, nor do I hope to enjoy it.
translation_text.mn75:15.1: Suppose there was a person affected by leprosy, with sores and blisters on their limbs. Being devoured by worms, scratching with their nails at the opening of their wounds, they’d cauterize their body over a pit of glowing coals.
translation_text.mn75:15.2: Their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a surgeon to treat them.
translation_text.mn75:15.3: The surgeon would make medicine for them,
translation_text.mn75:15.4: and by using that they’d be cured of leprosy. They’d be healthy, happy, autonomous, master of themselves, able to go where they wanted.
translation_text.mn75:15.5: Two strong men would grab them by the arms and drag them towards the pit of glowing coals.
translation_text.mn75:15.7: Wouldn’t that person writhe and struggle to and fro?”
translation_text.mn75:15.10: Because that fire is really painful to touch, fiercely burning and scorching.”
translation_text.mn75:15.12: Is it only now that the fire is really painful to touch, fiercely burning and scorching, or was it painful previously as well?”
translation_text.mn75:15.13: “That fire is painful now and it was also painful previously.
translation_text.mn75:15.14: That person was affected by leprosy, with sores and blisters on their limbs. Being devoured by worms, scratching with their nails at the opening of their wounds, their sense faculties were impaired. So even though the fire was actually painful to touch, they had a distorted perception that it was pleasant.”
translation_text.mn75:16.1: “In the same way, sensual pleasures of the past, future, and present are painful to touch, fiercely burning and scorching.
translation_text.mn75:16.2: These sentient beings who are not free from sensual pleasures—being consumed by craving for sensual pleasures, burning with passion for sensual pleasures—have impaired sense faculties. So even though sensual pleasures are actually painful to touch, they have a distorted perception that they are pleasant.
translation_text.mn75:17.1: Suppose there was a person affected by leprosy, with sores and blisters on their limbs. Being devoured by worms, scratching with their nails at the opening of their wounds, they’re cauterizing their body over a pit of glowing coals.
translation_text.mn75:17.2: The more they scratch their wounds and cauterize their body, the more their wounds become foul, stinking, and infected. But still, they derive a degree of pleasure and gratification from the itchiness of their wounds.
translation_text.mn75:17.3: In the same way, I see other sentient beings who are not free from sensual pleasures being consumed by craving for sensual pleasures, burning with passion for sensual pleasures, indulging in sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn75:17.4: The more they indulge in sensual pleasures, the more their craving for sensual pleasures grows, and the more they burn with passion for sensual pleasures. But still, they derive a degree of pleasure and gratification from the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
translation_text.mn75:18.2: Have you seen or heard of a king or a royal minister of the past, future, or present, amusing themselves supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation, who—without giving up craving for sensual pleasures and dispelling passion for sensual pleasures—lives rid of thirst, their mind peaceful inside?”
translation_text.mn75:18.6: On the contrary, all the ascetics or brahmins of the past, future, or present who live rid of thirst, their minds peaceful inside, do so after truly understanding the origin, disappearance, gratification, drawback, and escape of sensual pleasures, and after giving up craving and dispelling passion for sensual pleasures.”
translation_text.mn75:19.1: Then on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
translation_text.mn75:19.4: Of paths, the ultimate is eightfold—
translation_text.mn75:19.5: it’s safe, and leads to freedom from death.”
translation_text.mn75:19.6: When he said this, Māgaṇḍiya said to him,
translation_text.mn75:19.8: How well said this was by the worthy Gotama!
translation_text.mn75:19.9: ‘Health is the ultimate blessing; extinguishment, the ultimate happiness.’
translation_text.mn75:19.10: I’ve also heard that wanderers of the past, the tutors of tutors, said:
translation_text.mn75:19.11: ‘Health is the ultimate blessing; extinguishment, the ultimate happiness.’
translation_text.mn75:19.13: “But Māgaṇḍiya, when you heard that wanderers of the past said this,
translation_text.mn75:19.14: what is that health? And what is that extinguishment?”
translation_text.mn75:19.15: When he said this, Māgaṇḍiya stroked his own limbs with his hands, saying:
translation_text.mn75:19.16: “This is that health, worthy Gotama, this is that extinguishment!
translation_text.mn75:19.17: For I am now healthy and happy, and have no afflictions.”
translation_text.mn75:20.1: “Māgaṇḍiya, suppose a person was blind from birth.
translation_text.mn75:20.2: They couldn’t see sights that are dark or bright, or blue, yellow, red, or magenta. They couldn’t see even and uneven ground, or the stars, or the moon and sun.
translation_text.mn75:20.3: They might hear a sighted person saying:
translation_text.mn75:20.4: ‘White cloth is really nice, it’s attractive, stainless, and clean.’
translation_text.mn75:20.5: They’d go in search of white cloth.
translation_text.mn75:20.6: But someone would cheat them with a dirty, soiled garment, saying:
translation_text.mn75:20.7: ‘Sir, here is a white cloth for you, it’s attractive, stainless, and clean.’
translation_text.mn75:20.8: They’d take it and put it on, expressing their gladness:
translation_text.mn75:20.9: ‘White cloth is really nice, it’s attractive, stainless, and clean.’
translation_text.mn75:20.11: Did that person blind from birth do this knowing and seeing,
translation_text.mn75:20.12: or out of faith in the sighted person?”
translation_text.mn75:20.13: “They did so not knowing or seeing,
translation_text.mn75:20.14: but out of faith in the sighted person.”
translation_text.mn75:21.1: “In the same way, the wanderers of other religions are blind and sightless. Not knowing health and not seeing extinguishment, they still recite this verse:
translation_text.mn75:21.2: ‘Health is the ultimate blessing; extinguishment, the ultimate happiness.’
translation_text.mn75:21.3: For this verse was recited by the perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas of the past:
translation_text.mn75:21.6: Of paths, the ultimate is eightfold—
translation_text.mn75:21.7: it’s safe, and leads to freedom from death.’
translation_text.mn75:21.8: These days it has gradually become a verse used by ordinary people.
translation_text.mn75:21.9: But Māgaṇḍiya, this body is a disease, a boil, a dart, a gloom, an affliction. Yet you say of this body:
translation_text.mn75:21.10: ‘This is that health, this is that extinguishment!’
translation_text.mn75:21.11: Māgaṇḍiya, you don’t have the noble vision by which you might know health and see extinguishment.”
translation_text.mn75:22.1: “I am quite confident that the worthy Gotama
translation_text.mn75:22.2: is capable of teaching me so that I can know health and see extinguishment.”
translation_text.mn75:22.3: “Māgaṇḍiya, suppose a person was blind from birth.
translation_text.mn75:22.4: They couldn’t see sights that are dark or bright, or blue, yellow, red, or magenta. They couldn’t see even and uneven ground, or the stars, or the moon and sun.
translation_text.mn75:22.5: Their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a surgeon to treat them.
translation_text.mn75:22.6: The surgeon would make medicine for them,
translation_text.mn75:22.7: but when they used it their eyes were not cured and they still could not see clearly.
translation_text.mn75:22.9: Wouldn’t that doctor just get weary and frustrated?”
translation_text.mn75:22.11: “In the same way, suppose I were to teach you the Dhamma, saying:
translation_text.mn75:22.12: ‘This is that health, this is that extinguishment.’ But you might not know health or see extinguishment,
translation_text.mn75:22.13: which would be wearying and troublesome for me.”
translation_text.mn75:23.1: “I am quite confident that the worthy Gotama
translation_text.mn75:23.2: is capable of teaching me so that I can know health and see extinguishment.”
translation_text.mn75:23.3: “Māgaṇḍiya, suppose a person was blind from birth.
translation_text.mn75:23.4: They couldn’t see sights that are dark or bright, or blue, yellow, red, or magenta. They couldn’t see even and uneven ground, or the stars, or the moon and sun.
translation_text.mn75:23.5: They might hear a sighted person saying:
translation_text.mn75:23.6: ‘White cloth is really nice, it’s attractive, stainless, and clean.’
translation_text.mn75:23.7: They’d go in search of white cloth.
translation_text.mn75:23.8: But someone would cheat them with a dirty, soiled garment, saying:
translation_text.mn75:23.9: ‘Sir, here is a white cloth for you, it’s attractive, stainless, and clean.’
translation_text.mn75:23.10: They’d take it and put it on.
translation_text.mn75:23.11: Their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a surgeon to treat them.
translation_text.mn75:23.12: The surgeon would make medicine for them:
translation_text.mn75:23.13: emetics, purgatives, ointment, counter-ointment, or nasal treatment.
translation_text.mn75:23.14: And when they used it their eyes would be cured so that they could see clearly.
translation_text.mn75:23.15: As soon as their eyes were cured they’d lose all desire for that dirty, soiled garment.
translation_text.mn75:23.16: Then they would consider that person to be no friend, but an enemy, and might even think of murdering them:
translation_text.mn75:23.17: ‘For such a long time I’ve been cheated, tricked, and deceived by that person with this dirty, soiled garment when he said,
translation_text.mn75:23.18: “Sir, here is a white cloth for you, it’s attractive, stainless, and clean.”’
translation_text.mn75:24.1: In the same way, Māgaṇḍiya, suppose I were to teach you the Dhamma, saying:
translation_text.mn75:24.2: ‘This is that health, this is that extinguishment.’
translation_text.mn75:24.3: You might know health and see extinguishment.
translation_text.mn75:24.4: And as soon as your vision arises you might give up desire for the five grasping aggregates.
translation_text.mn75:24.6: ‘For such a long time I’ve been cheated, tricked, and deceived by this mind.
translation_text.mn75:24.7: For what I have been grasping is only form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
translation_text.mn75:24.8: My grasping is a requirement for continued existence. Continued existence is a requirement for rebirth. Rebirth is a requirement for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.
translation_text.mn75:24.9: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.’”
translation_text.mn75:25.1: “I am quite confident that the worthy Gotama
translation_text.mn75:25.2: is capable of teaching me so that I can rise from this seat cured of blindness.”
translation_text.mn75:25.3: “Well then, Māgaṇḍiya, you should associate with true persons.
translation_text.mn75:25.4: When you associate with true persons, you will hear the true teaching.
translation_text.mn75:25.5: When you hear the true teaching, you’ll practice in line with the teaching.
translation_text.mn75:25.6: When you practice in line with the teaching, you’ll know and see for yourself:
translation_text.mn75:25.8: And here is where diseases, boils, and darts cease without anything left over.’
translation_text.mn75:25.9: When my grasping ceases, continued existence ceases. When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases. When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.
translation_text.mn75:25.10: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”
translation_text.mn75:26.1: When he said this, Māgaṇḍiya said to him,
translation_text.mn75:26.3: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.
translation_text.mn75:26.4: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn75:26.5: May I receive the going forth, the ordination in the worthy Gotama’s presence?”
translation_text.mn75:27.1: “Māgaṇḍiya, if someone formerly ordained in another sect wishes to take the going forth, the ordination in this teaching and training, they must spend four months on probation. When four months have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, they’ll give the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.
translation_text.mn75:27.2: However, I recognize individual differences in this matter.”
translation_text.mn75:27.3: “Sir, if four months probation are required in such a case, I’ll spend four years on probation. When four years have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, let them give me the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.”
translation_text.mn75:28.1: And the wanderer Māgaṇḍiya received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.
translation_text.mn75:28.2: Not long after his ordination, Venerable Māgaṇḍiya, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, realized the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.mn75:28.3: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”
translation_text.mn75:28.4: And Venerable Māgaṇḍiya became one of the perfected.
